title: 103_hr3844
content: The Act may be cited as the "Brownfield Cleanup and Redevelopment Revolving Loan Fund Act". The Congress finds that contaminated and underused industrial sites in distressed communities face economic challenges in securing funding for cleanup and redevelopment. These properties, once cleaned up, can provide significant public benefits and promote environmentally sound practices. Voluntary cleanup programs encourage private sector involvement in remediation efforts. The purpose of this Act is to revitalize distressed communities by providing loans for cleanup of industrial properties to attract private investment, foster clean manufacturing, and create jobs for local residents. States can use Federal funds to capitalize revolving loan funds for local cleanup and redevelopment projects. The Act aims to revitalize communities by providing loans for cleanup of industrial properties to attract private investment, foster clean manufacturing, and create local jobs. States can use Federal funds to establish revolving loan funds for cleanup and redevelopment projects. SEC. 3 focuses on creating a revolving loan fund for cleanups under state voluntary cleanup programs. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will establish a loan program for States to receive capitalization loans for voluntary environmental cleanups. States must submit an approved application to establish or expand a revolving loan fund. The application must include evidence of a voluntary cleanup program for eligible facilities with adequate public participation opportunities. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a loan program for States to receive capitalization loans for voluntary environmental cleanups. States must provide evidence of public participation opportunities and a matching share of at least 20 percent of cleanup costs. Additionally, States must describe their revolving loan program and capability to manage it. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a loan program for States to provide loans for voluntary cleanups. Borrowers must demonstrate credit worthiness and the ability to carry out the cleanup. Priority will be given to facilities planned for industrial reuse with environmentally sound practices and those creating jobs for local contractors. The Environmental Protection Agency will establish a loan program for States to provide loans for voluntary cleanups. Borrowers must demonstrate credit worthiness and the ability to carry out the cleanup. The State must provide a statement of repayment within 5 years and show evidence of repayment ability. The loan cannot be used for new construction, environmental fines, speculative assessments, or rehabilitation with little economic potential. Other elements may be included as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The Administrator will determine distribution of funds among eligible States for capitalization loans. The loan amount cannot exceed 15% of the total available to all States. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1995, and $7,500,000 for each of fiscal years 1996 and 1997. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. An "eligible facility" under this Act is a property in a State with environmental contamination that hinders its use, development, or reuse, but excludes facilities eligible for abatement under another Act or currently under Federal enforcement action. An "eligible facility" under this Act includes facilities on the National Priorities List, facilities requiring permits under the Solid Waste Disposal Act, land disposal units with closure notifications, and facilities undergoing corrective action. An "eligible facility" under this Act includes facilities subject to corrective action, facilities for response activities under the Solid Waste Disposal Act, and facilities owned by the US government.
